text: BEFORE THE ARBITRATOR

text: In the Matter of the Arbitration of a Dispute Between
label: BODY

text: R.W. MILLER & SONS, INC.
label: HH1

text: and

label: HH1

text: Case 1

label: BODY

text: Attorney Daniel D. Barker, for the Company.

text: ARBITRATION AWARD
label: HH1

text: Pursuant to the joint request of the parties, I was assigned by the Wisconsin
label: BODY

text: Employment Relations Commission to arbitrate a grievance arising under the terms of the
label: BODY

text: 1999-2003 contract between R.W. Miller & Sons, Inc. and Teamsters Local Union No. 43.
label: BODY

text: Hearing was held in Lake Geneva, Wisconsin on January 18, 2001. A stenographic
label: BODY

text: transcript of the hearing was prepared and the parties agreed that the transcript was the official
label: BODY

text: record of the proceedings.
label: BODY

text: The parties filed post-hearing briefs and the record was closed on March 20, 2001
label: BODY

text: when I received a letter from the Company advising that it would not be filing a reply brief.
label: BODY

text: ISSUE
label: HH1

text: The parties were unable to agree on a statement of the issue to be decided but did agree
label: BODY

text: that I could frame the issue after considering their respective positions.
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: The Union asserts the issue is:
label: BODY

text: Did the employer violate the collective bargaining agreement by not awarding
label: BODY

text: the cold roller job open on May 5, 2000 to the grievant?
label: BODY

text: If so, what is the appropriate remedy?
label: BODY

text: The Company contends the issue is:
label: BODY

text: Did the Company violate Article 4, Section 1 of the collective bargaining
label: BODY

text: agreement when it refused to transfer John Laskowski from his assignment on
label: BODY

text: the crushing machine to the cold roller?
label: BODY

text: If the Company violated this Article and Section, what is the appropriate
label: BODY

text: remedy?
label: BODY

text: Having considered the parties’ positions, I frame the issue as:
label: BODY

text: Did the Company violate the contract by denying the cold roller
label: BODY

text: job
label: BODY

text: the
label: BODY

text: grievant and, if so, what remedy is appropriate?
label: BODY

text: PERTINENT CONTRACT LANGUAGE
label: HH1

text: ARTICLE 4. SENIORITY
label: HH3

text: Section 1. Seniority, with ability and qualifications, shall govern in
label: HH1

text: advancement to higher rated jobs. For other than seasonal work, employees will
label: BODY

text: be called back to work by seniority in their classifications.
label: BODY

text: ARTICLE 34. MAINTENANCE OF STANDARDS
label: HH3

text: Section 1. The Employer agrees that all conditions of employment in his
label: HH1

text: individual operation relating to wages, hours of work, overtime differentials,
label: BODY

text: and general working conditions shall be maintained at not less than the highest
label: BODY

text: standards in effect at the time of the signing of this agreement.
label: BODY

text: Page 3
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT “A”
label: HH1

text: Drivers, driver operators, and mechanics engaged in doing excavating, grading,
label: BODY

text: paving and batch work, water, gas pipe, sewer and tunnel work, asphalt and all
label: BODY

text: black top, snow removal, ashes, cinders, sand, gravel, stone, gravel pit
label: BODY

text: stripping and utility men covering:
label: BODY

text: A. New employees who have
label: BODY

text: never driven trucks for this
label: BODY

text: Employer before, first 90 days of
label: BODY

text: employment
label: BODY

text: B.  Truck drivers after 90
label: BODY

text: calendar days of employment
label: BODY

text: C.  Combination truck driver &
label: BODY

text: machine operator & mechanics
label: BODY

text: POSITIONS OF THE PARTIES
label: HH1

text: The Union
label: HH2

text: The Union asserts that the Company violated Article 4, Section 1 and Article 34,
label: BODY

text: Section 1 when the Company denied the grievant the cold roller job in May, 2000.
label: BODY

text: As to Article 4, Section 1, the Union contends that the cold roller job is a “higher
label: BODY

text: rated” job than operating the crusher because of the potential to earn “white sheet” wages.
label: BODY

text: Because the grievant had the “ability and qualifications” to operate the cold roller and had
label: BODY

text: more seniority than the employee given the job by the Company, the Union argues that the
label: BODY

text: grievant was entitled to the job under Article 4, Section 1.  The Union disputes the Company
label: BODY

text: contention that the grievant’s attitude or temper disqualified him from the job. The Union
label: BODY

text: assert that such factors are not “qualifications”, that the grievant has never been disciplined for
label: BODY

text: his attitude or temper, that there is no significant evidence that the grievant’s attitude or temper
label: BODY

text: is any worse than other employees, and that there is no documented evidence that the
label: BODY

text: grievant’s attitude or temper have affected job performance.
label: BODY

text: As to Article 34, Section 1, the Union argues that when jobs have been posted, lateral
label: BODY

text: transfers such as the one sought by the grievant have always been awarded based on seniority.
label: BODY

text: Under such circumstances, the Union asserts that the maintenance of standards language in
label: BODY

text: Article 34, Section 1 was violated when the grievant was denied the cold roller position.
label: BODY

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: The Union asks that the Company be ordered to cease and desist from violating the
label: BODY

text: contract, place the grievant in the cold roller position, and make him whole for any losses.
label: BODY

text: The Company
label: HH2

text: The Company initially argues that issue to be resolved in arbitration should be limited
label: BODY

text: to the violation of Article 4, Section 1 alleged in the grievance. The Company asserts that
label: BODY

text: where, as here, the grievance makes no mention of a past practice or a maintenance of
label: BODY

text: standards clause argument and there is no evidence that such issues were discussed during the
label: BODY

text: processing of the grievance, it is inappropriate to consider them now.
label: BODY

text: As to the alleged violation of Article 4, Section 1, the Company contends that because
label: BODY

text: the request transfer was not to a “higher rated job,” Article 4, Section 1 does not apply and
label: BODY

text: that the Company was free to assign the roller job as it saw fit.  The Company argues that the
label: BODY

text: only contractually recognized basis for “rating” jobs is by pay classification and points out that
label: BODY

text: the roller job is in the same pay classification as the crusher work the grievant was performing
label: BODY

text: at the time of the transfer request.  Arguments that the roller job is “higher rated” because of
label: BODY

text: the potential for earning “white sheet” wages or because the roller job is “easier” should be
label: BODY

text: rejected as being speculative, subjective, unworkable and without contractual support.
label: BODY

text: If the Article 34 maintenance of standards issue is entertained, the Company argues that
label: BODY

text: it did not violate this contractual provision because the clause does not apply to the exercise of
label: BODY

text: management rights such as job assignments and because there is no binding past practice to be
label: BODY

text: maintained. The Company contends that job assignments are not “general working conditions”
label: BODY

text: within the meaning of Article 34, Section 1. As to the alleged existence of a past practice, the
label: BODY

text: Company alleges that there is no consistent, mutually accepted practice of  awarding a lateral
label: BODY

text: transfer to the most senior bidder.
label: BODY

text: Lastly, the Company argues that even if it is concluded that Article 4 or 34 generally
label: BODY

text: require that lateral transfers be awarded based on seniority, the grievant was not entitled to this
label: BODY

text: transfer because he did not have the ability to perform the work to the Company's satisfaction.
label: BODY

text: The Company asserts that its judgement that the grievant’s temperament would prevent the
label: BODY

text: efficient functioning of the paving crew is not arbitrary and capricious and thus should not be
label: BODY

text: second guessed.
label: BODY

text: Given all of the foregoing, the Company asks that the grievance be denied.
label: BODY

text: DISCUSSION
label: HH3

text: I begin with the issue of whether the dispute before me is limited to the Article 4,
label: BODY

text: Section 1 violation alleged in the grievance or also includes consideration of whether
label: BODY

text: Article 34, Section 1 was honored by the Company.
label: BODY

text: Page 5
label: BODY

text: The Company correctly notes that arbitrators generally will not decide claims that are
label: BODY

text: raised at the first time at the arbitration hearing.  However, absent specific contrary language
label: BODY

text: in the grievance procedure, where the claim remains the same but additional arguments or
label: BODY

text: contractual provisions are cited in support thereof, arbitrators generally conclude that they have
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction to consider the additional arguments/contractual provisions.  Here, I conclude that
label: BODY

text: the claim has remained unchanged (i.e. did the grievant have a contractual right to the roller
label: BODY

text: job?) and the Union at hearing advanced an additional contractual argument in support of that
label: BODY

text: claim.  Under these circumstances, I am persuaded that both Article 4 and Article 34 are
label: BODY

text: before me for consideration.
label: BODY

text: As to the alleged violation of Article 4, Section 1,  the Company persuasively argues
label: BODY

text: that because the two jobs in question are both Class C jobs for the purposes of wage rates, the
label: BODY

text: grievant was not seeking a transfer to a “higher rated job” within the meaning of Article 4,
label: BODY

text: Section 1.  The only way the contract explicitly “rates” jobs is by hourly wage rate and use of
label: BODY

text: phrase “higher rated” as opposed to “better” conveys an intent to exclude factors such as
label: BODY

text: whether a job might be “easier.”  For the same reasons, I reject the argument that the potential
label: BODY

text: for “white sheet” earnings is a factor in how a job is “rated” under Article 4.  Hourly wage
label: BODY

text: rate is the only explicit contractual rating of jobs and the formality of the phrase “higher rated”
label: BODY

text: conveys an intent to exclude other considerations which might make a job “better”- including
label: BODY

text: the potential of “white sheet” earnings.  While such additional factors clearly will play a role
label: BODY

text: when an employee decides whether to bid on a different job, these factors do not play a role
label: BODY

text: when determining how a job is “rated.”
label: BODY

text: Because the consideration of seniority under Article 4 is limited to “advancement to
label: BODY

text: higher rated jobs,” and because I conclude that moving from the crusher to the roller is not
label: BODY

text: “advancement to a higher rated job,” I find that the Company’s action did not violate Article 4.
label: BODY

text: While the Company is free to consider seniority in such circumstances, it is not contractually
label: BODY

text: obligated to do so by Article 4.
label: BODY

text: Turning to Article 34, the contract requires that the Company maintain
label: BODY

text: . . . all conditions of employment in his individual operation relating to
label: HH3

text: wages, hours of work, overtime differentials and general working
label: BODY

text: conditions . . .  (emphasis added).
label: BODY

text: Because the transfer right asserted by the grievant is not a “wage,” “hour of work” or
label: BODY

text: “overtime differential”, the question becomes whether it is a “general working condition”
label: BODY

text: within the meaning of Article 34.  I conclude it is not.  While it can well be argued that a
label: BODY

text: practice as to transfers is a “condition of employment,” Article 34 only protects those
label: BODY

text: “conditions of employment” that are “general working conditions.”  I am persuaded that the
label: BODY

text: contractual phrase “general working conditions” does not include transfer practices but rather
label: BODY

text: Page 6
label: BODY

text: are generally limited to matters such as the physical conditions under which work is
label: BODY

text: performed.  Thus, I concluded that the Company’s conduct did not violate Article 34.
label: BODY

text: Given all of the foregoing, I deny the grievance.
label: BODY

text: Dated at Madison, Wisconsin this 31st day of July, 2001.
label: BODY

text: Peter G. Davis, Arbitrator
label: BODY

text: PGD/gjc
